div.p: 1. V:15. A Mr W. A. Scholfield came to the Office to make enquiries, on the subject of the arbitration of the question between us and Great-Britain; upon the construction of the first article of the Treaty of Ghent; and our claim of indemnity for Slaves carried away by British Officers after the conclusion of the Peace— I told him the state of the reference to the Emperor of Russia, according to the advices last received. I received a Letter from General S. Smith of Baltimore, enclosing one to me from C. Hughes at Stockholm, which had been accidentally opened— Wrote a Letter to A. Gallatin, with a copy of the Report on Weights and Measures, and forwarded to his care other copies for the Prince de Talleyrand, and the Chevalier Delambre— Mrs. Adams resumed this Evening her weekly tea-party.

2. VI:Mrs Adams quite unwell. I wrote a despatch to A. Gallatin, concerning the Negotiation with the Baron Hyde de Neuville; and despatched with it copies of the correspondence between the Baron and me, since the 30th. of March— I sent also Copies of the Report to each of the foreign Ministers residing here, and copies for the Royal Societies and the Academy of Sciences of France, to Mr Canning and the Baron de Neuville— The latter to be forwarded by Mr La Foret who is going immediately as a Messenger with the Baron’s despatches to France.

3. IV:45.Mrs. Adams went to Alexandria, to see her sister, Mrs Hellen. Philip Scheihing the German boy who has lived with us since October 1817 left us— He was bound to me for 6 1/2 years; three of which are yet unexpired. But at his own and his father’s repeated solicitations I have consented to discharge him, upon condition, that he shall serve the remainder of his time as an apprentice to learn a mechanical trade— Mr Lambert came to make application for instruments from the engineer Department at the War-Office, for the Observations to determine the Latitude and Longitude of the Capitol. and Major Roberdeau came, and tried with me the experiment of filling the measures of capacity received from England, copies from the Standards in the Exchequer, with Water as a trial of their dimensions— We filled them from a narrow necked glass decanter, containing 60. 1/2 cubic inches, and by this measurement found the Winchester Bushel to contain 2126. and the coal bushel 2224 cubic inches—agreeing very exactly with the result of the admeasurement by the depth and diameter. The Corn Gallon contained 272. and the wine Gallon 231 cubic inches— The Quart 70 and the Pint 35 inches. I walked after dinner, and spent the Evening at Mr Calhoun’s.

4. V:30.Edward Wyer came to the Office, and brought his Report, upon his mission to Haÿti; Mr Peter Lanman of New-York, brother of the Senator from Connecticut came to solicit an Office in Florida— In the beginning of September 1789. I accidentally travelled in a Stage from Boston to Providence, and then in a small packet Sloop from Providence to Newport, with this Peter Lanman— We were then little more than 20 and nearly of the same age— We formed a sort of intimacy in the course of the three or four days that chance had thrown us together, but I had not seen him again till this day. He was then in the heyday of youth and Spirits— His countenance has now the marks of care and misfortune—almost haggard— E. Patterson who is to furnish paper for the printing of the Census came for an advance of payment without which he said he should be unable to furnish it— Patterson is a home manufacturer, and therefore must be encouraged; but he has no Capital; without which it is scarcely possible that any such manufacture should flourish; he has not much activity or intelligence, and there is no dependence to be placed upon his engagements. He must be encouraged by taking from him Articles of inferior quality and at higher prices than the like Articles would bear, imported from abroad. I wrote a Letter to the
Earl of Carysfort to enclose with a copy of my Report upon Weights and Measures. Evening Unwell.

5. V:30.The Russian Minister Poletica called at the Office, and shewed me in confidence a Letter of Instructions from his Government, giving a general view of the Emperor’s policy, as essentially pacific. Setting forth some complaints against the Porte, but manifesting the intention of maintaining the utmost moderation in the relations of Russia, with that power; and speaking with strong disapprobation, and alarm at the Revolution in Spain— Edward Wyer came again, and made further verbal report of the execution of his mission to Haÿti. He speaks in terms of high respect and esteem of Mr Inginac the Secretary of State to the Mulatto President Boyer— Commodore Rodgers called; going upon an excursion to Boston— I was at the President’s and communicated to him the substance of the despatch which had been read to me, by Mr Poletica— At 5 O’Clock I attended a Meeting of the Columbian Institute; and afterwards spent the Evening at the Baron Hyde de Neuville’s. Amused with Chess. Despatched also this day, a Letter written yesterday to R. Rush, on Weights and Measures, and my Report.
6. V:30. Heard Mr Little at the Bath Room. From 1. Peter 3.8. “Finally, be ye all of one mind, having compassion one of another; love as brethren, be pitiful, be courteous.”
